text: Yeah. What was interesting was what I saw anyway was the reasons I mentioned previously, post-08 funds, the value prop of hedge funds in general, but I'm really going to focus on long-street equity funds started to be questioned. And really things like the liquidity, that was a recurring refrain I heard from other institutional investors was, why does it take me four quarters to get out of this long-street equity fund when they're trading publicly traded equities? And so the other side of that too, and where I really started to see it kick off was Madoff. And so I'll never forget, I'm not going to say funny, but this is a really interesting story. Mark Freed was sitting at the Bloomberg one day and he called into one of the other partner's offices and he's like, hey, they finally caught Bernie. And I'm like, who's Bernie? And he's like, oh, it's this guy that nobody really knew what was going on, but the rumor was that he was front-running his clients. He came in here, one of his feeder funds came in here and you know, he was like, I'm going to call him. And he's like, I'm going to call him. And he's like, he's like, it's interesting. Bloomberg's saying it was a Ponzi scheme. He's like, I don't know. But anyway, obviously that all unfolded. Interestingly, I also went back to the original access database that he had. And sure enough, one of the feeder funds was in there with the returns. And I looked at the score and it was interesting that it had been kicked out as a unreasonable outlier or something like that. But Madoff, back to that point, Madoff was when I really started seeing from the institutional investors that we dealt with the demand for SMAs go up. Yeah. Transparency, liquidity. And that's when, again, I'm importing my own biases on this, but that's when I really started to see the replicator landscape take off just from an interest level. And it was, for better or for worse, it was a very disparate landscape. So there was the idea, like you said, Lowe kicked off the idea of statistical replication. I think Merrill was the one. We went through that exercise very closely, replicated the results from Lowe's paper to within basis points. He kind of gave the whole recipe there. We saw that, I think it was Merrill had launched a note off of that paper to within basis points. And so the immediate thing we did was just take that model. And what was interesting was Lowe used five fixed factors. So he just kind of said ahead of time, we're going to identify a priori five factors, if I remember correctly, that would have economic justification for being the underlying drivers of returns for hedge funds. And those were static factors, factors that he used to in this kind of rolling window approach against the HFRIW index. So this dependent variable comprised of all hedge fund strategies, the results were encouraging. Kind of the obvious, and he mentions this in his paper, but the obvious next step would be, all right, there's no reason that you'd want to try and replicate all hedge funds as an asset class. Or if you did, you would want to run the regression on different, more homogenous dependent variables. And so that's what we did. We already have this database. So we just dropped in. We just dropped in our long short equity index into that model. And the R-squareds were higher. And it's worth noting too, that these are out of sample R-squareds because it was a rolling window analysis. That was one of the early criticisms or questions we got was, yeah, but this is in sample. And so Lowe talks about this. Fung and Shea were two guys at a Duke that had done a lot of early work on extending kind of the Fama French model to seven and eight factor models for hedge fund returns. And so as a quant, I was sitting there saying, all right, this is appealing because it is truly out of sample. And so we're going to try and replicate that. And so we're going to try and we also constrained the universe to ETFs. We did a stepwise process to allow the constituents of ETFs to change from month to month. So we didn't fix five factors. We broadened the landscape a little bit and we started getting really compelling results, out of sample R-squareds of 95% on our long short equity funds. And so that was interesting. I'm going to pivot a little bit though, get back to your comment about the zeitgeist of the area. So meanwhile, so the low paper had kind of kicked off the ETFs. And so we did a stepwise process to allow the constituents of ETFs to change the idea of statistical replication, using a top-down regression approach. Meanwhile, I believe it was Mark Malik over at Conquest, which was a well-known managed futures, had kind of taken a different approach where he talks about the... He published a paper called the beta of managed futures, where he used some kind of momentum. I think he used average true range or one of the more kind of technical indicators in the managed futures universe. But his point was trend following or within the managed futures landscape can be thought of as its own asset class or its own risk premia. And he kind of mechanically replicated a rule set that would harvest or seek to efficiently and effectively harvest that risk premia. And so that was kind of the other side of it, was this statistical approach, this mechanical approach. And then you had the 13F replicators, which was a good idea in theory. But I remember I saw one of the Bloomberg reporters at a conference where I was talking about the idea of hedge fund replication. He came up to me, he's like, what do you think about the new guru ETF that's coming out? And we looked at the... It hadn't launched yet. So we pulled the file prospectus and looked at it. And again, it was a great idea. But the problem was they were looking at, if I remember correctly, the top 100 hedge funds by AUM, and then just kind of pulling off the long positions from the 13F because shorts aren't required to be reported and holding that as a portfolio. And there was some rebalancing. I'm assuming it was quarterly rebalancing around the 13F cycle. But if you look at the hedge funds that they were replicating, they were replicating the 13F cycle. And so they were like, I don't know if we're going to get any more hedge funds. So they were like, you know, renaissance was one of the top ones. And so I told this guy, I was like, I don't have any particular insights into renaissance, other than Simons is clearly a genius. But they themselves will tell you. I mean, the turnover in their book is like, I don't know, 15 minutes or something. Like a quarterly point in time snapshot of the stocks they hold is going to have zero persistence or forward-looking predictive ability in terms of the constellation of their portfolio. And then you think about other end of the spectrum. It's like, I think Angelo Gordon, the distractor who was running around the world a lot of times was like, fund was one of the top 100 by AUM. Well, the 13Fs is only going to be kind of stub post IPO type positions that they got stuck with, or it's not going to be an accurate reflection of the risks that they're intelligently underwriting. And so my point was, it was a perfect example of kind of a good idea. But what I would argue is a mediocre or subpar implementation. And so I mentioned that because all of those approaches kind of got lumped in as hedge fund replicators. And so there was a lot of early criticism where people were pointing to these things and saying, hey, 13Fs can't replicate what Seth Klarman's doing. Meanwhile, the statistical approaches can't replicate non-publicly traded asset classes, like post real equities or things like that. We were kind of waving the flag saying, all of that is accurate. However, if you really refine the universe that you're looking at, allow the ETFs that you're using as explanatory, and ultimately proxies to trade the strategy to vary a little bit, you can get really compelling results. And so that was just to finish this up. That was when we kind of sat there and decided, all right, this is 2010 at this point. Let's start putting firm money in this for the long short equity clone portfolio, as it was called. And then just start tracking this real time.
